turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in California against the United States.
Mr. Walston, I think you may proceed when you are ready.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may I please the Court.

The issue before the Court today is whether Section 8 of the Reclamation Act of 1902 requires the Secretary of the Interior to comply with state regulatory water laws when he acquires and uses water under that particular Act.

Section 8 embodies a fundamental historical principle of the federal reclamation laws, a principle that within some yet undefined limits the states have some measure of control over the use in the distribution of such water.
Thus, the principle in this case is one of ultimate historic significance, we believe.
It is whether that substantive principle of the federal reclamation laws will remain a viable principle of those laws.
During my argument this afternoon, I intend to focus on what we consider to be the three major issues before the Court.
First, did Congress in fact, in 1902, establish a principle of state control of water, did Congress actually give that power to the states?
Secondly, if it did, how do we reconcile that principle with the many substantive Congressional policies that Congress has enacted in the field of reclamation, both in the 1902 Act and in later Acts?
In other words, how do we reconcile potential conflicts between state and federal policies?
Third, how do we reconcile the principle of state control with the broad discretion which Congress has given to the Secretary of the Interior to carry out the substantive Congressional policies?
Now, let me turn to the facts of the case.
The Reclamation Act of 1902 essentially provides for federal construction and operation of reclamation facilities in about 17 western states.
Under the authority of that Act, Congress has authorized a number of reclamation facilities in California that are collectively known as the Central Valley Project.
The Bureau of Reclamation has always complied with California regulatory water laws in acquiring its water rights for the Central Valley Project.
It has always submitted permit applications to the California Resources Control Board.
The Board has always granted permits to the Bureau.
The Board has usually imposed conditions in those permits.
The Bureau has always complied with the conditions in the permits.
In fact, since 1927 the State Board had issued 12 major decisions that result in the issuance of conditional permits to the Bureau of Reclamation.
Then, in 1973, the United States filed its present action for declaratory judgment.

In this action, it asked the court to determine that the Bureau of Reclamation need not comply with California’s appropriation procedure and, thus, that it need not comply with conditions in the permits which have been issued to the Bureau.
The affect of this position, of course, would be to void the conditions in all 12 decisions which have been issued by the State Board.
A way of illustration, the United States in its complaint referred to a specific decision called Decision 1422.
This decision results in the issuance of conditional permits to the Bureau of Reclamation for the New Melones Project on Stanislaus River in California.
The New Melones Project is a dam and reservoir facility that was authorized by Congress in 1944 and it was reauthorized in 1962.
In its complaint, the United States argues that the State Board lacks power under and any and all circumstances to impose any kind of condition upon the federal water right.
In California, by way of contrast, argues that California has a qualified power to impose conditions.
It argues that it can impose conditions if those conditions do not impair or interfere with the basic Congressionally authorized purposes of federal reclamation projects.
The lower court upheld the position of the United States.

It held that the State Board is without power to impose conditions under any and all circumstances, that there is not circumstance where such a condition can be imposed upon an appropriate permit issued to the Bureau.
On that basis, the court granted summary judgment for the United States.

The court did not reach the question whether the conditions of Decision 1422 or for that matter any other decision issued by the State Board, in fact, conflict with any Congressionally authorized purposes of the project.
It avoided that question because it held the question was simply not relevant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was the phrase “Congressional authorized purpose of the project” one gotten out of the legal literature or used by the State of California or by the United States?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: It reflects the position of the United States, Justice Rehnquist.
We have maintained throughout this litigation that the state has the power to impose conditions under Section 8 of the Reclamation Act, which I will momentarily describe.
We also will point out momentarily that Congress has, subsequent to 1902, adapted a number of reclamation policies and established the individual reclamation projects.
In our view, every time Congress establishes such a policy or authorizes such a project, it subtracts from the authority which it originally gave the states in 1902.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if Congress said “we want to have the New Melones Project and we are going to appropriate all vested water rights in the State of California that are inconsistent with the operation of that.”
Would you think Congress could do that if it simply set it forth in the Authorization Act?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Yes, very definitely.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Consistently with the Gerlach Live Stock case?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Yes.
As I understand Gerlach, the court was merely holding that in that particular case Section 8 required reference to state law.
What you are suggesting in the hypothetical, Justice Rehnquist, that Congress might override Section 8.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What power do you suppose it would be exercising if it did that?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I think that it would have that power under either the commerce clause or the property clause of the United States Constitution.
There are decisions of this Court, by the way, going back to 1907 that give a contrary view.
For instance, in Kansas v. Colorado, this Court seems to suggest that Congress did not have that constitutional power.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What subsequent cases have suggested that it does have that power?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: We think that a fair analysis of this Court’s decisions in Ivanhoe and Fresno would support the concept that Congress has that its constitutional power because, in those cases, the Court essentially held that Congress could override state water laws in specific areas.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not vested water rights?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Not vested water rights?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did you really mean the answer to Justice Rehnquist that if there had been adjudicated water rights in the State of California without condemning them and buying them?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Congress could certainly condemn them under the authority --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what he asked you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Can they simply say “they are now ours” without condemning them?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: No, I do not think so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You answered that they could.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I was assuming a broader question perhaps from Justice Rehnquist.
I thought you were talking about unappropriated water generally, Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you agree that if appreciate right that has been adjudicated, that United States must comply?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Absolutely, very definitely, but that is not the issue.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, let us talk about the unappropriated water.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: The unappropriated water, that is correct.
That is the issue here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What power do you say?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: With respect to unappropriated water, we think United States would have the power under the commerce clause and the property clause of the US Constitution to acquire such water.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you find any case in this Court that names those two particular powers?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I would say that this Court’s decision in the Beaver Portland case, for example, holds that the states essentially have the right to control the unappropriated water of the western states, but is subject to two major Congressional constitutional limitations.
One limitation is found in the commerce clause and the other is found in the property clause.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What power do you suppose United States is exercising to build a reclamation project at all?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I think it can exercise that power under either the commerce clause or the property clause.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You do not think the welfare clause?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Possibly also.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is the way this Court has talked about reclamation projects --

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I think that in the Ivanhoe case, the Court did make reference to the welfare clause, but I think that the traditional approach that this Court has taken in most cases has been to rely on the commerce clause and the property clause.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What cases ever relied on the commerce clause to support the taking by the United States of unappropriated water in a situation that did not involve a navigational servitude as well?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That did not involve a navigational servitude?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I cannot think of any.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I cannot either.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: The Court has usually held that the commerce clause and the navigational servitude are essentially the same.

In its 1899 decision in Rio Grande, it seem to suggest that there might be a commerce clause power to take water as part of the navigational servitude, but I do not think this Court has ever held that where navigation is not concerned, Congress has powers under the commerce clause to take unappropriated water.

I hate, of course, to be defending the position of the United States in this litigation at this point, but essentially, what we are really talking about in this case is whether Congress in fact required the Bureau of Reclamation to comply with state law in acquiring unappropriated water.
The issue in the case is precisely that.
Did Congress in Section 8, provide that the Bureau of Reclamation must comply with state water laws?

If the State Board lacks a qualified power to impose any kind of conditions on the federal water right, then the conditions of all 12 decisions, which the State Board has issued, including the Decision 1422, would be void.
If, on the other hand, the State Board has that power, then the conditions of all 12 decisions, we think, are beyond collateral.

In fact, for the reason that United States has never chosen to seek direct judicial review of any of those decisions and in any event, surely, the Court cannot examine the conditions of any particular decision in this case because that matter was not before the lower court and the lower court did not take any evidence on the question.

This brings me to what I consider to be a first major question before the Court and that is whether Congress, in fact in 1902, established the principle that the states have the right to control water from the Federal Reclamation Projects under the 1902 Act.
Section 8 specifically provides that the Secretary shall “proceed in conformity with state laws relating to the control, appropriation, use, or distribution of water.”

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let me ask you one question which is I see you are starting a new part of your argument, a follow up of the earlier colloquy we had.

Supposing the State of California had a homesteading program whereby state-owned land was made available to citizens of California who were willing to reside there for two years and the United States came in and said “we find that it is just necessary to take a lot of this homestead land for the New Melones Project.”
Do you think it would have the right to do that without paying California for it?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: No, I do not believe that it would.
I do not believe that there is any decision of this Court which would support the United States in that endeavor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then why do you think that Congress has the right to take unappropriated water from the state?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Maybe because there has never been adjudication from this Court as to who owns the water in the non-navigable streams?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is true and this Court has always avoided that question.
In fact, in the 1945 decision in --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there has been one as to who owns the water in the navigable streams, has there not?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I do not recall that off hand.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: As to who has the navigational servitude control?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Not in terms of ownership.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, not in terms of ownership.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not in terms of ownership, that is the point.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Correct, the Court has never held that United States owns the unappropriated water of the western states.
It has held, however, that the United States might have some overriding constitutional powers that enable it to act and establish a certain degree of control over those waters.
But it has not actually established that United States has the power to actually own the water itself.
Let me turn now to the language of Section 8 itself.
The Section, on its face, requires the Secretary to proceed in conformity with state laws relating to the control, appropriation, use, and distribution of water.
On its face, this Section clearly requires federal compliance with state appropriation laws. State appropriation laws, in turn, provide for state regulatory control of water.
This is the way the states control the water.
They control the water through their appropriation laws.
They determine the beneficial use of their water.
They thus manage and control their limited water supply.
Thus, the Section on its face, requires the federal government to be treated as a private appropriator under the state’s appropriation laws.
Essentially, the United States makes two arguments with respect to the meaning of Section 8.

First, it argues that the Section does not require the Secretary of the Interior to comply with state laws relating to unappropriated water, but that the Secretary merely does so as a matter of comity.
He does not have to do it.
He simply does it because he chooses to do it.
Secondly, the United States argues that if Section 8 actually requires him to comply with state laws, it requires him only to comply with the so-called forms of state law.
The forms of state law are defined by the United States as consisting of all state laws other than those that provide for regulatory control of water.
This conclusion, we think, is wholly inconsistent with the language of Section 8 itself.

The language says that the Secretary shall proceed, not may proceed or could proceed or should proceed, but shall proceed in conformity with state law and, thus, suggest that he does not do so as a matter of comity.
Secondly, the Section specifically refers to state laws relating to the control of the use and the distribution of water.
Those are the words in the Section itself, control, use, and distribution.
These are terms, obviously, that include state regulatory control.

The result which we suggest is even more clear we think, under the legislative history of the Reclamation Act of 1902 and with the Court’s indulgence, I would like to just briefly make reference to a couple of selected portions of the legislative history that we think shows the overwhelming sentiment of the 1902 Congress for the principle of state control.
If the Court would, I would like to refer to our brief in the case which is the blue brief, the brief for the petitioners.

You turn first, if you would, to page 25 and just listen to the language of Congressman Mondell of Wyoming who is the floor leader for Section 8 and in fact, the entire reclamation bill when it was before the House of Representatives.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Page 25 of your brief, right?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Yes, that is correct.
That is the blue brief.

Upon halfway down in the italicized portion of the brief, Congressman Mondell states, “the Secretary of the Interior would proceed to make the appropriation of the necessary water by giving the notice and complying with the forms of the law, of the state, or territory in which the works are located.”
The United States essentially concedes that that language is not consistent with its comity argument, but it makes the argument that this language is consistent with its so-called form argument.

Without arguing that point, without arguing whether Congressman Mondell actually meant to suggest a distinction between the forms and the substance of state law, it is very clear from other portions of the legislative history that no such distinction was intended.
For instance refer, if the Court would, to page of 27 of our opening brief.

Again, Congressman Mondell speaking, this is the quote that appears near the top of the page, “Section 8 follows the well-established principle and national legislation of recognizing local and state laws relative to the appropriation and distribution of water and instructs the Secretary of the Interior in carrying out the provisions of the Act to conform to these laws.”

Back on page 24, the floor leader for the bill in the senate, Senator Clark of Wyoming stated, this quotation appears halfway down the page, “it is right that in the general government should control, should conserve, and should reservoir the headwaters of these streams, in this it is a national and not a state proposition, but in the distribution of these waters, it is right and proper that the various states and territories should control in the distribution.
The conditions in each and every state territory are different.
What would be applicable in one locality is totally and absolutely inapplicable in another.”
The United States essentially makes no response --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you undertake to tell me what you think the senator meant precisely by that?
What kind of condition is this?
Is he talking about Minnesota where we have a surplus of water as compared with a state where they have a shortage of water, or just what?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Essentially, Senator Clark was referring to all the western states, we believe, which all have a lack of water.
There is very little water in all the western states, but essentially, the water he was talking about was unappropriated water because that is the one the federal government normally requires --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The differences that you seem to be emphasizing, what differences can you suggest he was talking about?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: The differences between what, Mr. Chief Justice?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What would be applicable in one locality totally and absolutely is inapplicable in another?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Well, some states have and some portions of states have highly developed metropolitan areas.
Other states and other portions of other states have undeveloped rural areas.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: This is might be comparing Montana or Wyoming with California.
Is that what you have in mind?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Right, exactly.
In California, for example, we need water for purposes that may not exactly apply in Montana or Wyoming.
Wyoming needs water for agriculture and irrigation primarily.

California and especially the developed metropolitan areas of California need water for municipal use because of certain environmental balances and, in fact, in some cases imbalances in these states, water in some instances, must be made available for environmental protection.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you think this was all apparent to Congressman Mondell in 1902?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: No, not at all.
I think in 1902 Congress was just getting this program off the ground.
They felt that the best way to proceed would be to proceed by having the Secretary of the Interior comply with state law because the states had always controlled their unappropriated waters.
In fact, this Court had recognized the tradition a number of times, that the states traditionally control their unappropriated waters.
The same tradition was recognized by Congress back in the Mining Acts of 1866 and the Dessert Land Act of 1877.
The states essentially have traditionally controlled their unappropriated waters and Congress in 1902, quite evidently, wanted to continue and extend that tradition.

An examination of the administrative practice, that occurred after the 1902 Act was passed, shows, I think quite convincingly, that Congress was actually successful in its effort to provide for state control of water because the Secretary of the Interior has, in fact, consistently and fully complied with state regulatory water laws in acquiring and using his water under the Act.
For instance, in California, the Bureau of Reclamation has always acquired appropriative permits from California.
California has traditionally imposed the conditions in those permits and the Bureau has always complied with those conditions.

Until this case, it never sought to destroy those conditions, but in this case, the United States is advancing the argument that the Secretary only complied with those state laws as a matter of comity.
We think that that is entirely inconsistent with everything that the Secretary of the Interior has said ever since 1902 onward with respect to his obligation under Section 8.
In fact, even the current operating regulations of the Secretary of the Interior embrace the principle of state control.
Let me just read from these.
These appear at page 39 of our opening brief.
These are the current regulations of the Bureau.

“The Reclamation Act recognizes the interests and rights of the states in the utilization and control of their water resources and requires the Bureau in carrying out provisions of the Act to proceed in conformity with state water laws.”

Since the construction of a reservoir and the subsequent storage and release of water for beneficial purposes normally entail stream regulation, it is necessary to reach an understanding with the states regarding reservoir operating limitations.
Thus, the Secretary has always complied with state law.
He has always said that he is required to do so under Section 8.

In this case, the United States was essentially trying to change the rules of the game, 76 years as it were after the game was started, it is essentially trying to break and destroy the historic relationship that has guided --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Of course, there is no problem unless there is a conflict?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: There is no problem unless there is a conflict.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is our position, Justice Marshall.
Let me turn to that just briefly.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The possibility was that, all along, it worked because there was no conflict during the 77 years.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I think that is true.

In other words, the states were traditionally imposing conditions that did not conflict with specific Congressional policy and, thus, under those circumstances the Secretary complied with those conditions.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In other forms, when states ruled conflict with Congress’ rules, what happened?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Usually, when the state conflicts with Congress, Congress prevails.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Absolutely.
We concede that the same result applies here, Justice Marshall.
Let me address that question more in detail.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I appreciate it.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Obviously, since 1902, Congress has established a number of substantives of reclamation policies.
It has established and enacted, in fact, four different Acts that essentially amend the Reclamation Act of 1902.
On top of that, it authorizes individual reclamation projects that have basic Congressional policies behind them.

Some experts in the field of water law and especially some advocates of the state’s rights position have argued that Section 8 literally imposes no limits on state control, and therefore, none should be implied, thus, under that view the states would have the right to override substantive Congressional policies and have the right to exercise a veto power over the projects.

The difficulty with that view, of course, is what you are suggesting, Justice Marshall, and that is that the states could, under those circumstances, completely obliterate the Congressional objectives that led to the enactment of the Federal Reclamation Program in the first place.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In addition, I think it would be hard to put to find a western state law school that did not teach water law and you will not find any eastern ones either?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that not just a fact?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is certainly true.
I suppose that is true.

I think that there are some staunch advocates of the position I have just pointed out, certainly in the western water schools, but at the same time, that is not the view we are urging, Justice Marshall.
I want to make that very clear.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You recognize the fact that California needs water?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What eastern state needs water?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: The eastern states just do not have the problem the western states do.
So that is why the Reclamation Act only applies to the western states.

The United States, by the way, makes the argument that in order to preserve these Congressional objectives I just talked about, the Secretary of the Interior should have absolute control of water uses under the Reclamation Act of 1902.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have nay water law?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That might be a very good policy argument, but it is simply inconsistent with what Congress did in 1902.
It is inconsistent with Section 8 and the principle of state control that is embodied in Section 8.
Thus, our view is this.
We think that these various principles can be harmonized and reconciled.
We think that the principle of state control should apply only to the extent that it is consistent with what Congress has actually intended to accomplish in the field of Reclamation.
In other words, where there is a clash or conflict between Congressional policy and state policy, then obviously, Congressional policy overrides.
On the other hand, if there is no such conflict, then state law applies and that is to say that the states cannot override what Congress has done.
By the same token, the Secretary of the Interior cannot override what the states have done if the states have acted consistently with basic Congressional policy.

In other words, a federal bureaucrat in Sacramento cannot decide to sell water to an irrigation district on the north side of the Sacramento River rather than the south side, and then claim that his decision represents Congressional policy and then claim that because his decision represents Congressional policy, his decision overrides state law.

Because, if the Secretary has that power and state law has no room in the federal reclamation scheme and under those circumstances, the principle of state control on Section 8 which had been honored for 76 years simply does not exist.
In fact, this I think was the approach which this Court took in two cases, in the 1950s and the 1960s in the Ivanhoe and the Fresno cases.

In Ivanhoe, state law conflicted with the basic Congressional policy that provides for an acreage limitation and that is found in Section 5 of the Reclamation Act of 1902 and the Court said state law does not apply.
It cannot conflict with the specific Congressional policy.

In Fresno, state law conflicted with the specific principle of the federal reclamation laws found in the 1939 Act that provides a preference for water for irrigation purposes over municipal purposes and the Court, again said state law cannot apply under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Who did the adjudication here, the Water Board?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: The California State Water Resources Control Board.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, suppose that there had been a determination by the federal authority so that these deficiencies in the federal scheme that the Board found were resolved, that they did have a need for the water, they had established a need for the water and etcetera, and suppose they needed then irrigation and the federals have done as much as they possibly could to establish this need, now I take it you would not suggest that the Board could say “we just do not allow water to be used for irrigation in this state?"

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is a correct statement of our position, Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, because of some specific provision in the Federal Act, I take it.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: No, because of an interpretation of Section 8 in light of the purposes of the Act which authorize the individual project in question.
In other words, Congress, in authorizing specific reclamation projects, always had basic purposes in mind.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the state’s position is that if Congress makes a determination that if there is any unappropriated water in California and it decides clearly and finally to use some water for irrigation and they have a project to develop the water, that the California Board must appropriate the water to it for use of irrigation even though some state agency wanted to use it, it would have to save it for municipal purposes?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: On what basis do you give that answer to that question?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Going back to your original question, Justice Rehnquist, we think that Congress has the power under the commerce property and general welfare clauses to use the western states' unappropriated water in whatever ways are consistent with those particular clauses.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: As I understand the general welfare clause, as interpreted in the United States v. Butler, it was said that he it gave Congress a power to tax and spend for the general welfare without being required to refine further authority under the commerce clause or some other affirmative grant of power, but do you concede what Justice White’s hypothetical poses to you, it is simply being an exercise of a power to spend?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is the way I read this Court’s decision in the Ivanhoe case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You would say that it would also be sustainable in the commerce clause?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Right, exactly.
If the Court wants to back off of them, we are certainly not going to try to discriminate it in doing so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You would be delighted with that.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You would be delighted with that.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I should think so.

It would certainly give the states more control, but at the same time, I think it is very important for the Court to bear in mind that California is equally interested in the achievement of basic reclamation objectives established by Congress.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And water saving?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is correct.
We do not really perceive that there is any conflict between what California is trying to accomplish in this field and what Congress is trying to accomplish.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But Justice White’s question did pose to you a conflict, I would think, where there the federal government comes in and says “we want to use this water for our irrigation,” and the state law says “domestic use has priority,” and the Water Appropriation Board says “we have 18 applicants for domestic use who can only be partially satisfied.”
You say, nonetheless, the government’s claim must prevail for irrigation?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Yes, that is correct.
We are conceding hypothetically that there could be a conflict, and if there is a conflict, that must be resolved in favor of Congress.

But I am pointing out, Justice Rehnquist, that in actual fact there have been no such conflicts of any measurable degree between what the states have been trying to accomplish and what Congress has been trying to accomplish.
There is no such conflict even in this case.
The conflict in this case is not between Congress and the State of California.
It is between the State of California and the Secretary of the Interior.
The Secretary of the Interior is essentially trying to proceed with a number of plans in California that have no mandate under Congressional law.
He is trying to proceed with plans that were not considered or mandated by Congress.
Thus, we feel what we are doing is quite consistent with what Congress had in mind in the field of reclamation.
Thus, there is no clash ultimately in this case between federal and state policy.

That brings me, I think, to the third major question which I would like to address and that is how we actually resolve the principles we have been talking about with the broad grant of discretion which has been given to the Secretary of the Interior by Congress.
The United States’ argument essentially is this.
It argues that Congress has established a very broad comprehensive reclamation scheme and has vested the Secretary of Interior with broad discretion to carry out that scheme.
This scheme is so broad, according to the United States, that it leaves no room for state control at all.
The Secretary of the Interior has discretion to override state water laws whenever he chooses to do so.
Thus, the United States is really posing perhaps the ultimate issue in this case and let me phrase it this way.

Has Congress in fact enacted a comprehensive reclamation scheme that in fact leaves no room for state regulatory control or instead does the comprehensive scheme established by Congress include state regulatory laws?

To phrase the proposition differently, does the Secretary have a plenary discretionary authority to override state law whenever he wants to do so or instead does Section 8 limit his discretion by requiring him to comply with state law where there is no basic conflict between state law and Congressional policy.
I hope the Court has no illusions with respect to the effect of the argument being advanced by the United States.

If that argument is upheld, then Section 8 will have no practical effect because the entire principle of state control will be subservient to the discretion of the Secretary of the Interior and thus will not exist.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if under a particular Reclamation Act however that the Congress gives to the Secretary rule-making authority to do certain things and until he does them, there is no conflict with the state and when he does, there is a conflict.
Arguably, at least then Congress has overridden its Section 8 itself.
Section 8, after all, is just a statute and Congress can amend it expressly or impliedly?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: But under the circumstances you gave, Justice White, we do not see that there would be any potential conflict between state and Congressional policy.
We think that the Secretary will be required in exercising his discretion to carry out state policy if he can possibly do so.
Thus, the question is whether it is possible for the Secretary to carry out his obligations under both state and federal and Congressional policy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say that Section 8 is an implied circumscription of the Secretary’s authority?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Right, correct, exactly.

In other words, when Congress gives discretion to the Secretary, it limits it by requiring him to comply with state law to the extent that he can do so consistently with his other obligations under the Reclamation Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In some statutes, they have repeated Section 8, but not all of it?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: When you say some statutes, do you mean statutes that authorize individual projects?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I think, Justice White, that in all statutes the Secretary is required to operate the projects “pursuant to the federal reclamation laws” which includes Section 8.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if there happen to be a specific provision in a future reclamation statute and specific Congressional provision that would require something that would not be required?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then, it would override Section 8?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Precisely.

In other words, if Congress instructs the Secretary of the Interior in its authorizing Act to provide water in Area 'A' of the State of California, for sure, the State of California cannot come along and say that water has to be used in Area 'B'.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if it says “in such areas as the Secretary shall, in his complete discretion, determine”?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Well, that is a very good question, Justice White and I think there you get into the question of how you interpret Section 8 in light of the discretion given to the Secretary.

Our view would be that under those circumstances, the Secretary’s discretion is still limited by Section 8 in that if he can comply with state law without violating a specific Congressional mandate, he must do so.
If the result is otherwise then Section 8 just does not mean anything.
The reason I say that is because the Secretary has broad discretion under the various federal reclamation laws.
Congress has given him discretion to sell water.
Congress has given him discretion to get money from people who purchase the water.
If that discretion in simply selling the water is deemed to override state laws that might otherwise condition to sell that water, then Section 8 is nullity.
It simply does not exist and Congress has constantly reaffirmed the principle of state control, and therefore, we do not believe that it meant to, thus, repeal Section 8 by implication.
That is what the United States is really arguing in this case.
It is arguing that Section 8 has been repealed by implication.

In our view, the Section mandates the partnership between Congress and the states and under that partnership, it is Congress and not the states which set the basic reclamation policies of this country, but within that framework, the states are free to act.
The Secretary does not have discretionary authority to destroy that partnership by coming in and overriding a state law that maybe fully within that Congressional parameter.
The result which we are suggesting to the Court is one we think harmonizes and reconciles the various reclamation laws that have been established by Congress.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can I interrupt you?

It all sounds very easy, but you often get ambiguous statutes and you often refer to the Secretary as Head of an agency and construing his authority, how do you decide which way to resolve the conflict?
Does the State Water Board always resolve the dispute?
How do you get these boarder line decisions determined?
Who has the dispute resolution power?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: They have not really existed in the past too much because there has been a great accommodation between federal and state agencies of California.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I think we have to assume that this case indicates there are such possible conflicts?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I am not sure there are such possible conflicts.

I think this case raises the question whether the states have the right to impose any kind of conditions on the federal water right regardless of whether those conditions may or may not impair to Congressional policy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you say they have the power to impose some conditions?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But not conditions which conflict with Congressional policy?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And if the Secretary takes the view that the condition does conflict with Congressional policy, how do you decide whether it does or it does not?
Who decides that?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Ultimately, that question would have to be answered by the Courts.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You always have litigation over that?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I do not think there would always be litigation.
In fact, as I said, the case comes to this Court on the bare legal question whether the states have the right to impose any kind of conditions under any circumstances.

Once that question is established, I do not think the federal government and the western states are going to be running to the Court all the time to determine whether a particular condition or conditions are consistent with Congressional policy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The potential for that dispute produced 170-page brief in this case.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is for sure.
Yes, the potential is there, Justice Stevens.
I cannot ignore that.
We are not asking the Court to adapt an easy view.

If the court wants to adapt the easy view, then obviously, it ought to uphold the position of the United States, but because there is no conflict under the United States’ view, all conflicts would be resolved in favor of the Secretary’s discretionary authority.
The states would not have control at all.
But we think that Section 8 imposes upon this Court an obligation to examine such potential conflicts as may exist, Section 8 can be read in no other way.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Just so I get it right.
The state imposes a condition.
Say, you are going to impose some conditions, you impose 10 conditions, the United States thinks four of them conflict with the policy of the Act.
They then have to file a declaratory judgment action, that is the way they do it then?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: We think that they would be required to pursue California’s mandamus remedies.
In the other words, I would say the federal government would be required to seek direct judicial review of those particular conditions.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: California review in the state judicial system, they could not bring suit in the federal district court and ask for declaratory judgment?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: We think that the suit in the first instance ought to be brought in the State Court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, the federal question.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: I was just going to say that, certainly, there would be no problem with the United States removing such a case to the Federal Courts.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Maybe arguing it in the Federal Court?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Or starting it.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Or starting in the Federal Court.
That raises the question whether the United States would be required to pursue its state judicial remedies as well as comply with state administrative procedures.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Walston.
Mr. Barnett.
If you could, Mr. Barnett, the states have just operated that sufferance of the federal government in these areas, somewhere in your discussion, if you would treat that problem?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may I please the Court.
I do not think that is the case, Mr. Chief Justice.

I do not agree with Mr. Walston that if the Court holds for the United States in this case that means that the United States sweeps the field and that the states are completely excluded from any role in the planning of reclamation projects or in the formulation of reclamation policy.
On the contrary, we submit that there is and always has been a coordination and a consultation between the states and the federal government and that that is illustrated by this very case.

Indeed, there are aspects of this case which demonstrate that what the State of California was trying to do here is to upset and override at least one accommodation that had been reached with respect to the New Melones Project and if you will, I will get to that in time.

I am referring to the water quality agreement which was an actual memorandum of agreement made between the United States Bureau of Reclamation and the California Central Valley Regional Water Quality Control Board with respect to water quality functions of the New Melones Dam.
What the State Board has done in Decision 1422, as I will elaborate in more detail perhaps later, is they simply override that agreement, unilaterally rewrite it.
Thus, we would submit that what the state is trying to do here is to change the rules.

It is the state and not the federal government which is trying to change the rules that have existed for the past 70-add years and that have an honor to a rough accommodation of the conflicting state and federal interest in this area.

It is the United States’ submission, of course, that all four of the judges who ruled on this case in the courts below were correct that Section 8 of the Reclamation Act of 1902 does not authorize a state to impose conditions on a federal reclamation project such as the 25 conditions that were imposed here.
On the point on which the two courts below differed, we do not here challenge the ruling of the Court of Appeals.

That is that the Court of Appeals ruled that the United States is required by Section 8 to file applications with the State Board for permits to appropriate the water it needs for it reclamation projects.
We had contended, as Mr. Walston said in the district court, that we are not by law to do that, that we simply do it as a matter of comity.
We have, in either event, always done it.
The Court of Appeals ruled that we are required by law to do it and as we state in our brief, we do not contest that ruling here.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The Court of Appeals came out about 100% opposite from this Court in Hancock v. Train, did it not?

The Court of Appeals, in this case, said you have to go through the forum, but you do not have to follow the substance and this Court, in Hancock v. Train, said you do not have to go through the form but you do have to follow the substance?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: There is an apparent anomaly, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, but in any event, we do not think it makes any difference here since we did in this case apply to the State Board for our permits.
Since it is our policy to do so, we do not contest the ruling that we are required to do so.

If a case were to arise where the state took such a position that we felt that we could not do so, that would be the case on that record in which the Court should decide whether we are indeed required to do so.
Mr. Walston has said little, indeed nothing in his argument and little in his briefs, about the 25 conditions that were imposed here by the State Board on the New Melones Project.

We feel it necessary to look with some detail at those conditions because, as Mr. Justice Stevens suggested, it may seem fine in the abstract to argue as Mr. Walston has, that the Congress can make the policy and the states may fill the gaps.

It may not be so easy in practice, in reality when you are building a dam and we submit that the facts of this project illustrate that difficulty and illustrate, just as Mr. Justice Stevens suggested, that there would be a lot of Court cases on precisely such issues as whether four or ten conditions were not consistent with what petitioners refer to as the specific or the basic Congressional policies behind a project.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Barnett, in the District Court or in the Court of Appeal, did you take the position as you do here that one must study the 25 conditions to decide whether the state can impose any conditions or not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: We took the position in both courts that the state had no right to impose any conditions.
It was petitioners, the State of California, who moved for summary judgment in the district court and the district court granted summary judgment in our favor.
We did not move for summary judgment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if you still maintain that they have no power to impose any conditions, why do we have to study the 25 conditions?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: For two reasons, one is that the Court might not agree with us and we might therefore --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you are going to the conditions without even arguing the first point, that is why I was puzzled about it.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: The other reason is that I think you have to look at the conditions to show why the state should have no power to impose any of them.
It is only by getting down into the dirt so to speak and looking at the nitty-gritty details that one sees what would be involved in the legal conclusion that petitioners are asserting.
We think it is necessary to look at the conditions in order to see just what the difficulties would be that would arise.
First of all, as Mr. Walston had stated, the New Melones Dam is a project that was authorized first by Congress in 1944 and reauthorized in 1962.
The project, as reauthorized, calls for a dam with a reservoir having a storage capacity of 2.4-million acre-feet.
This is on the Stanislaus River in California, of course.
The project, as authorized in 1962 tentatively, called for a hydroelectric power plant with a capacity of 150,000 kilowatts.

That was stated as tentative and as a result of subsequent consultations between the federal power commission and the Bureau of Reclamation, it was decided to raise the power capacity and it was raised to 300,000 kilowatts.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Barnett, is it the government’s position that it will own the 2.5 million square-feet of water that is stored behind the dam?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That it will own the water, no that is not our position.
That raises the question which was mooted with Mr. Walston and which the Court has really --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It is never answered.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: It has never answered the question of who owns unappropriated water.
Now, here the water would have been appropriated by the government, but I would say, we would still not claim that we own it.
We would be, in essence I think trustees for the people to whom we would sell the water or contract for the water pursuant to the Congressional legislation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you could, for instance, decide that that water should be used for irrigation and sell it to people who wanted to use it for irrigation even though, under California law, domestic use took higher priority and if that law prevailed, they could not use it here?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That would be our position, but that is not because we own the water.
It is because Congress, in the Act, has authorized us to build the dam and appropriate the water for the purpose of irrigation, among others.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yet, it is appropriated, you say, it is not bought, it is not condemned?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, because it was not owned.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Because it was not owned and, yet, it is simply somehow transmogrified by the existence of this project into something that is made available to people in California under a system of law that is not consistent with California’s?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That is true and that system of law arises, the law of this project arises from the Acts of Congress authorizing the project.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it then you would think that Congress could constitutionally pass an Act that says “we know the western states have been managing the appropriation of waters, but we are going to have a national system to appropriate the waters from all of the unappropriated water that exist in western streams.
We are going to have a national administrative operation to do it?”

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Congress would pay just compensation for those?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Unappropriated water.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Unappropriated waters?
I would think Congress could do that constitutionally, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In a sense, that is what you are saying.
In a sense, you had answered that question before when you answered Justice Rehnquist, that in the Reclamation Acts to some extent Congress does that?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes, I think that is correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What power is it acting under when it does that?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I think it is clear from cases like Ivanhoe that the power to spend for the general welfare and the property clause are two powers.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It has not spent any money buying these water rights though.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: It is not buying the water rights, but it is buying the dam.
It is spending money on the dam.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Take the example of California Homesteading project.
Supposing it builds a big dam right in the midst of California State Forest and says “we need the land from the State Forest to carry out the purpose of the dam.”
Do you think it could just take that?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: It may have to pay for it, but here we have got unappropriated water which is not owned.
This is the basic question that the Court had never decided, the ownership of unappropriated water.
The court has avoided the question in Nebraska v. Wyoming and Ivanhoe and it is one of those very basic, very controversial questions that we think are best avoided.
We contend here that when Congress authorizes a reclamation project, the effect of that authorization is to assert a federal claim to the water that is needed for that project.
Now, to the extent that water has already been appropriated, the federal government has to pay for it.

To the extent that that water is unappropriated, we say that Congress has authorized a federal claim which the states must accede to and thereby, must grant this federal government a permit for the unappropriated water if it is available.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Which you will enter with third parties for their actual use?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes, depending on the purposes of the particular authorizing Act.

In this case, the purposes of the particular authorizing Act are clearly that the water be turned over to third parties, except to the extent that it is to be used for recreation and the reservoir, for example.
Indeed the purposes of the Act, and what I would now like to mention because it is with them that the particular conditions have to be compared.
Petitioners here concede that the authorizing Act of this project had eight purposes: flood control, agricultural use of the water that is irrigation, municipal use, and industrial use.
Those are four, then fish and wildlife protection, water quality control, power generation, and recreation.
Pursuant to the Acts authorizing the project, the United States duly applied to the State Water Resources Control Board for permits authorizing it to appropriate the water needed for the project.
The United States filed four such applications, two of which were applications for transfers of applications previously filed by a State Board.
In brief and rubbing out some of the details, what the United States asked for in these applications was the following.
It asked for the a permit to store 2.4 million acre-feet annually, which would be in the reservoir behind the dam and it asked for the right to divert from the river 8,000 cubic-feet per second.
Both of these requests were for all eight of the project purposes, although, I am over simplifying somewhat.
Now, with respect to the purposes, there is a distinction that has to be born in mind and that is between instream and consumptive uses of the water.
For example, when it sought to divert water for the purposes of fish culture or downstream recreation or water quality control, for those purposes the water is released back into the river.
It is stored up in the spring when the water is high and then released in the summer when the river is low for water quality control or for fish or whatever.

Those, thus, are instream uses, to be distinguished are consumptive uses, whereby, the water does not go back into the stream and the consumptive uses are agricultural use that is irrigation or municipal or industrial consumption of the water.

The other of the eight uses, that is the use for power, is really an instream use. The water is diverted only momentarily through the penstocks of the hydroelectric plant and then goes into the stream.
Now, to look at the conditions, the 25 conditions that the State Board imposed in granting these permits and I of course do not propose to discuss all 25 of them.
We have discussed most of them in our brief.
I propose, here, to focus only on two or three of the most important.
In its decision, and this is at page 31 of Volume 2 of the Appendix, the State Board found there is unappropriated water available to satisfy the demands of the project as proposed.
But nonetheless, the State Board did not proceed to grant the permits for that unappropriated water that the United States was seeking, rather it imposed these 25 conditions.
Conditions one and two are the most important.
They respond directly to the amounts of water that the United States was seeking.
They substantially deny those amounts despite the Board’s finding that sufficient unappropriated water is available.
Again, to oversimplify somewhat what condition one does is that it grants permits for water, but only for certain purposes, not for other purposes that were authorized in the Act.

In brief, it grants permits for the instream purposes, but it denies the United States the right to store or divert water for the consumptive purposes of irrigational use or municipal or industrial consumption.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What do you understand to be their reason for that?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: They give their reasons, Mr. Justice White, in their opinion.

Their reasons are that, for example at page 23 of the opinion they say, the project’s recreational features would not adequately substitute for the present recreational uses of the river in the upstream reach, that is, they want to preserve the present white water rafting.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but what about the project?
There are some other reasons that Congress has failed to appropriate money for part of an anticipated project?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That, in fact, is a reason that petitioners come up within their briefs.
The Board, at no place, made that argument.
That is an argument that the Board’s counsel have made on appeal.
The Board did not say anything about Congress having failed to appropriate money for the east side division.
The Board did say, I should say, that the Secretary does not have a plan for the use of the water.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is what I thought.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: And it was on that basis that they say “since he does not have a plan for consumptive use of the water, we will not allow any water for consumptive use especially since if we allow the water for consumptive use that would fill the reservoir and that would wipe out the white water rafting.”

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is wrong with that reason for denying the permit?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: There are several things wrong with that reason.
One is that the Secretary, in fact, does have a plan.
The Act provides --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suppose he did not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Even if he did not, we would submit that it is not up to the State Board to trench on the authority that Congress has given the Secretary.
If it were true that, as Mr. Walston suggested at one point that the Secretary is acting beyond his Congressional authority, the remedy for that is not to go to the State Board.
The remedy for that would be to go to Federal Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That may be the remedy, but what is wrong with the Board saying “you have exceeded your authority.
You should not even be here asking or water, as far as we can tell,” is that beyond their cognizance?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Perhaps it would not be, but the Board here has not taken the position that the Secretary was acting beyond his Congressional authority.
They say that he does not have a plan for the use of the water.
There is nothing in the Act that requires him to have a plan before he gets the water.
It has traditionally been the Secretary’s practice to build a reservoir first and then make the contracts for the water, rather than vice versa.
Indeed, here, the Secretary has various plans.
The problem is that the Act provides that the Secretary must first determine the water needs of the Stanislaus River Basin before he can use the water for consumptive uses outside the Basin.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why is that, because of Congress?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That is what the Act says, the 1962 Act, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Secretary is, right now, in the process, has right now on his desk as it were, recommendations as to how to define the Stanislaus River Basin.
Once he defines the Basin, he will determine the needs of the Basin and then he will determine how much water can be sold outside the Basin.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How did he even know how much to ask for?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Congress authorized, on the basis of the project document, a reservoir of 2.4 million acre-feet on the basis of projected needs, both within the Basin and outside of it on the basis of projected needs.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: A part of that projected need is something that Congress has not appropriated the money for?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, Congress has appropriated the money for the dam.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is the project that your colleagues have referred to that has washed out?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That is the east side division that they refer to in their brief.
It was not brought up by the Board.
It is not the case, as petitioners claim, that the New Melones Dam was authorized only in connection with the east side division.
The east side division, incidentally is a canal, a proposed canal to bring water southward to the east side of the San Joaquin Valley.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that outside the watershed?
It is not, is it?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That would bring water outside the Stanislaus River Basin, that is true, but that was only one contemplated way of bringing water outside the Stanislaus River Basin to the service areas of the Central Valley Project.
There were and are many others.
The Board is considering many others.

Indeed, at the beginning of Decision 1422, this is at page 19 of Volume 2 of the Appendix, the Board itself states, the Bureau has described the following areas within which the conservation yield of the New Melones Project may be used for irrigation or for other consumptive purposes, the local service area consisting of Tuolumne, Calaveras, San Joaquin, and Stanislaus Counties.

Southern San Joaquin Valley via the proposed east side canal or a cross valley canal, the San Felipe division of the Central Valley Project, the San Luis unit of the Central Valley Project, the area served by the Delta-Mendota Canal, the Monta Zuma Hills unit of the Central Valley Project, and the Suisun Moshe area.

So it is not at all the case that simply because it may have been decided not to build the east side division and indeed, that decision was not made by Congress, that proposal never got to Congress as I understand it because the State of California did not endorse it, but it is not the case that simply because that particular proposal may have fallen through there are no uses for this water outside the Stanislaus River Basin.

If I may return to these conditions which I think are the heart of the case, as I was saying, condition one simply prohibits the federal bureau from diverting or storing water for the consumptive purposes that were among the purposes of the Act, that is, for irrigation or domestic or municipal or industrial consumption.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or around its consumptive purposes which have not been decided upon?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: But the Secretary is in the process of deciding them after he defines the need --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He just trying to (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Further, the condition one by limiting the size of the reservoir because the water cannot be stored for consumptive purposes, the size of the reservoir would be only 1.1 million acre-feet, not 2.4 million, there is a tremendous impact on the power that can be generated by the project and power is also one of the admitted purposes of the Act.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I know it would never happen, but if you did build a reservoir and dam that was too big, you could make it smaller.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That is true, but it seems unlikely in California or in the country that there will be a lack --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But do you not think California was right to say “what are you going to do with this water?”

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: The Act says that the Secretary is to determine the needs of the Basin and then to determine where to sell the water.
If California is trying to tell him he has to decide where to sell the water before he determines the needs of the Basin, then California is going against the Act.
In addition, it must be recognized as I know at the outset that the State of California has been in on the planning of this project all along.
They endorsed it initially before Congress in 1962.
This project has been no secret to the state.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Barnett?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I think you said, in substance, that the conditions are the heart of this case.
If your position is that California has no authority to impose any conditions, what difference does it make?
What do these conditions provide?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: As I said before, I think what these conditions provide is relevant to see why it should be the law that California has no authority to impose any conditions.
In addition, it is possible that the Court would want to look at the conditions individually and decide that some of them are acceptable and some of them are not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think the United States government is required to seek a permit from California?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: As I said at the outset, we do not contest that in this case.
We agree --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
