turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Because the Court of Appeals so ruled, because we make it a practice to seek such a permit because it serves legitimate federalism functions of informing the state of what we are doing.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As a matter of power, what would your answer be?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: As a matter of power, for purposes of this case, we concede that we are compelled to.
If another case came up where we thought that being compelled to was unacceptable to the federal policy involved, we would want to reserve the right on those facts to contest the issue.
We do not contest that here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I suppose the California Board determines whether or not there is sufficient unappropriated water?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes and the Board so determined here, as I read, that there is sufficient unappropriated water.
I might mention that it is not all the conditions here that we would contest.
In so far as conditions are concerned with whether unappropriated water is available, we do not contest those conditions.
For example, in this case, there are two conditions: 14 and 19, which we would not contest.
Condition 14 says that the Bureau of Reclamation does not authorize to collect water outside of the specified seasons.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That takes us back to when I suggested in a question at the outset.
This is by the grace of the federal government as a matter of generosity.
You inform the states, but you do not necessarily do any more than inform them and you accept their conditions when you find them acceptable?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I think that is correct.
That is the way we read the legislation.
We accept their conditions in so far as they relate to the availability of unappropriated water.
We do not accept their conditions in so far as they would trench on the operation or the structure even of the federal project.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if the California legislature were to next week to pass a law declaring that all unappropriated water in the state is hereby appropriated to beneficial users who will be determined by a commission appointed by the governor on the basis of existing California water law?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: That sounds as though that might pose the question that this Court has avoided deciding since the Dessert Land Act of 1877, that is, whether by that Act the federal government did give ownership of all unappropriated water to the states or not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There is no question that Massachusetts owns the unappropriated waters in its streams, is there?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Massachusetts has a Riparian Rights Doctrine and I do not know the answer to that, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Barnett, could you put a finger on a second or two on what you think it is that gives California or any of the other appropriation states the right to have a system of water law under which people can have their appropriations validated and acquire property rights?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I think it is a stream of federal legislation beginning with the Mining Act of 1966, including the Dessert Land Act of 1877 and including the Reclamation Act of 1902.

As we read the Act, the language that Mr. Walston was relying on and as we point out in our brief, was simply designed to continue that tradition of making clear that private rights to water on public land could be established by the State Doctrine of Prior-Appropriation.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Those Acts depended for their effect on the existence of public land in those states.
There never was any public land in the original time or the 13 original colonies.
So surely, they are not dependent on the sufferance of Congress or those Acts for any authority to determine water ownership, are they?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I suppose not, and I simply cannot answer the question as to who owns the flowing water in Massachusetts, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
I was mentioning power, what conditions one and two do to the power output.
In the record, page 146 of Volume 2 of the Appendix, there is an affidavit by Jay Robert Hamin (Ph) who supervised the power operations of the Central Valley Project.

As he points out, what the denial of the full water rights requested would mean would be that the firm capacity of the New Melones Power Plant would be reduced to zero, that is firm capacity as the capacity you can count on any day.
During the summer when the river is very low, you need water in your reservoir if you are going to be able to sell power.
He says the firm capacity would be reduced to zero.
The average kilowatts put out per year would be reduced from 430 million to 192 million.
The value of the power output would, thereby, be reduced from 5.5 million a year to 1.9 million a year.
He says this amount would not have justified the power plant investment in the first place. This is the kind of question that arises, Mr. Justice Stevens.
Petitioners would say it is necessarily inconsistent with --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I think petitioner would say if your facts are right, you would agree the condition is improper?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, they certainly do not take that position.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I thought he said that if the condition would interfere with the Congressional determination of what the statute is supposed to accomplish, the state had no power to hold it?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, I think we could ask him, but I think they would take the position that since Congress did not specifically say “we want $5 million worth of power a year” that this does not conflict with the specific Congressional purpose, but that is the kind of argument that the courts would be in.
How specific does Congress have to be?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Turning it around just a moment, I understood part of their reasoning to be that while you have got a lot of other water in this overall project and so you do not need this specific source for the time being at least for consumptive purposes, if they were right factually, would they not be right legally also?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I do not think so because Congress, one of the specific provisions of the 1962 authorizing Act written into the Act is that the New Melones Project shall become an integral part of the Central Valley Project and shall be operated as such by the Secretary of the Interior.
Now, condition four countermands that.

Condition four provides that no consumptive use of the water for New Melones may be made outside the Stanislaus River County unless it is demonstrated that no other Central Valley Project source is available to supply water to those particular areas.
Now, we would submit that that directly contradicts the language in the Act that this project shall be integrated with the Central Valley Project.
Petitioners would apparently say “that does not specifically contradict it for some reason because Congress did not specifically say something about it,” but we find it to be another --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if it is an integrated project and if the total project has enough water for those four counties, why is this condition an objection?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: If Congress thought that the total project had enough water available, it would not authorize this project.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I think it is a temporary thing, was it not? Did they not say, for the time being?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: What the 1962 Act says --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I meant that some of the conditions were temporary?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: They are all temporary in that they are subject to further order of the Board.
For example, Condition two says these limitations on the amount of water that may be diverted and impounded are subject to further order of the Board which shall be preceded.
I am reading from page 34 of Volume 2 of the Appendix.

Such further order shall be preceded by a showing that the benefits that will accrue from a specific proposed use will outweigh any damage that will result of fish, wildlife, and recreation in the watershed above New Melones Dam and that the permit he has firm commitments to deliver water for such other purposes.

The federal government would have to convince the State Board that the benefits of the use of this additional water outweigh the damages, as the Board sees them, to the fish, wildlife, and recreation in the watershed before this addition empowerment would be allowed.
Now, we submit that this is the State Board asserting for itself the power to determine what should be done with this federal project.
Should it be used for power or should it be used to preserve the existing white water above the dam and we submit that that is clearly inconsistent with the federal purposes behind this project.
Now, they would say “Congress did not say in the Act that power is more important than white water rafting,” therefore, the state can fill in the gap.
They talk a lot in their replay brief about how it has to be a specific federal policy that the state is going against.

Page 58-59 of their reply brief, if the state laws do not contradict the specific purposes of this scheme where specific elements of the Congressional scheme make it impossible to apply the principle, with specific federal policy or their emphasis incidentally.
We submit that it would be a very difficult, if not impossible thing to decide when it is a specific federal policy and when it is not.
Further, petitioners apparently take the position that Congress, to be sufficiently specific, has to say it in the statute.
Congress cannot delegate to the Secretary of Interior any administrative authority to make specific decisions, because then they say that state decisions would override.

We say that that is why this whole scheme that they propose, while it may seem fine in the abstract, when you apply it to a particular decisions of a particular project, it simply would not work and the federal courts, as you suggested, Mr. Justice Stevens, would become the ultimate arbiters of thus is a particular condition inconsistent or not with a federal project?
I would submit that federal judges, even Judge McBride in Sacramento are not suited to be the chief engineers for federal reclamation projects.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Barnett, would this only apply to California, this dam?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: This dam is only in California.
This river is only in California.
That is true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where does a federal government get the right to build a dam in the middle of a state without the state’s cooperation?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: First of all, it gets the right from the constitution, as has been held in Ivanhoe and other cases.
It is paying for the dam.
In addition, it had the state’s cooperation.
In the Appendix to our brief, we have the official statement of the State of California in 1962 endorsing this project.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could Congress, I would assume your answer would be yes, cut off the water for three other states and leave it all in one state?
Your answer has to be yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, I think Section 8 of the 1902 Act would prevent that where it provides that nothing in the Act can impair the rights of another state or an interstate river.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I take it you think that this Court has already, two or three times, construed Section 8 the way you think it should be construed.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I do.
I would know how Mr. Walston mentioned the Ivanhoe decision did not mention it at all.
City of Fresno or Arizona v. California, which we, of course, think make it very clear that this question has been decided.

In City of Fresno, one of the issues was whether the Reclamation Project water had to be delivered in accordance with California’s county of origin law, the very law that is involved here to some extent and the court ruled “no, it did not,” that the Secretary of the Interior did not have to follow that priority, similarly in Arizona v. California --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: To get back to my other question, and take out the two states.
They had build a dam and flood half of the state for the benefit of the other half.
There is nothing anybody could do about it.
Then, I would add to it, they would flood the Republican side --

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: The reality of these things, Mr. Justice Marshall, is these projects do not get constructed by Congress unless the state supports them.
That is why this east side division has not been authorized, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Waht I am -- All I am trying to get to is we have gotten along fine up to now by cooperating, state and federal. Do we not have to get back to that?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: We contend that that is where we are and that it is California that is trying to upset the balance.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does it not come down to this?
Does your position not necessarily come down to this that you are partners except that when you disagree, the federal government is the supreme partner?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: When we disagree about the operation or the uses of a federal reclamation project, under the present federal reclamation law, yes, that is our position.
There are, of course, proposals pending.

There are many pending proposals for changes in water policy, a number of them, indeed there are some on the President’s desk right now, as I understand it, a number of them provide for the states to share the costs with the federal government of reclamation projects.

Under that kind of a scheme, you might have a very different system, but our position is that, under the present law, where the state attempts to restrict or control the uses and operation of a federal project, the federal government must prevail.
With respect to the state federal cooperation aspect, I would like to mention also what I mentioned earlier, condition five has to do with water quality control.
By condition five, the State Board here would require the federal government to release certain amounts of water from the New Melones Dam to improve the quality downstream.

The federal government, in 1969, made an agreement, that the Bureau of Reclamation entered into a formal agreement which appears in the record here, whereby, it agreed with the Regional Water Quality Board of the Central Valley to release certain amounts of water from the New Melones Dam for the purposes of the water quality, but that agreement had limitations.
The Bureau said it could not release more than 70,000 acre-feet a year and if conditions were bad, it would have to limit the releases to the irrigation time of year.

What the Board has done here in condition five is rewritten that condition, rewritten that agreement, requiring the federal government to release whatever amounts would be necessary to maintain certain concentrations in the river without any such limitations.
Thus, this is an example of how you have existing cooperation.
Indeed, in this case, an existing formal agreement between the state and the federal government which the California State Board here is purporting to override.
We, thus, submit that it is not the federal government here which is against cooperation with the states.
The whole entire scheme of the reclamation laws, as we set out in our brief, involve state participation.
It is the state here which is trying to change the rules by asserting these unilateral conditions.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Barnett, can I ask one other question.
I was just looking at your complaint.
You did not ask for a declaration that all conditions be declared void, just those that were in contravention of federal law.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I think there was an amendment to the compliant.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I am sorry.
I see.
You are right.
It goes on which are not specifically authorized?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes, which are not specifically authorized.
If they are not specifically authorized by federal law then, we submit the states cannot impose them.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see
I am just wondering if it is possible if this case would be easier to decide if the Trial Judge had decided which conditions conflict with federal law and which do not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: We would submit that that is a terrible burden to impose on Trial Judges.
It is not just this project.
It is all projects.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you told us to study all 25 conditions in order to decide what the law is.
You imposed an awful big piece of effort on us?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: It might be easier here in a sense that we have tried to take the burden that the Trial Judge did not take.
We think that he was wise in declining to do that because he probably saw the difficulties that would entail.
Notice, further, that under petitioner’s theory it would have to be done forever.
They contend, for example, you cannot decide now whether some of these conditions are inconsistent with federal law.
You have to wait and see if the conditions are put into effect.

So it would not just be lots of conditions as to each reclamation project, but it would be a continuing series of operational decisions on their theory with respect to each project, all of which would be brought into federal court.

We submit that because of the difficulties of that kind of a process that those difficulties demonstrate why the very suggestion is unacceptable and why the law should remain, as this Court has held in its well-known Section 8 cases, that the states cannot impose conditions on federal projects.
If there are no further questions, I will sit down.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Walston, you have a few minutes left.

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
First, the United States makes the suggestion that there is no issue before this Court whether the federal government must in fact acquire appropriative permits under California law.

I would respond to that simply that the United States itself raised that very question in this litigation, in its prayer of relief and its complaint for declaratory judgment and that appears at Appendix one, page 19.
The lower court, responding to the United States’ argument, resolved the issue against the United States.
The United States is arguing that the Court should not consider the question here.
We think that would be an inappropriate way to resolve and pass up on the lower decision in this case.
The United States also has discussed at some length the various conditions which were actually imposed upon the Bureau of Reclamation in Decision 1422.
I caution the Court that there is much more at stake in this case than Decision 1422.
There are, in fact, a total of 12 decisions issued by California’s Water Resources Control Board that impose conditions upon the Bureau of Reclamation.
If United States’ claim is upheld in this case, then presumably the conditions in all 12 of those decisions are invalid, not just the conditions in Decision 1422.
The lower court did not actually evaluate the conditions that are involved in Decision 1422.
Thus, we do not think there is any kind of adequate record for the Court to examine that question here.

If the Court wants to consider that question, it should either decide that the matter has been resolved against the United States or must be resolved against the United States because it did not seek direct judicial review of the conditions, and therefore, is barred by the Doctrine of Resu Dicta or alternatively, should remand the case to the lower court so that it can itself consider the validity of those conditions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: To hold for you that we have to disembowel Arizona v. California to some extent and Ivanhoe?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: No, not at all, Justice White.
Arizona involved a very peculiar situation that arose under the Boulder Canyon Project Act.
The court, in that case construed the meaning of the Boulder Canyon Project Act which of course involved a reclamation project that utilized the waters of many different states.

The court held that the legislative history showed that the federal government under that Act was to have absolute control of water and that any other system would not work because otherwise the project would be subject to the various and even inconsistent commands of different state legislatures, but the Reclamation Act of 1902 has an entirely different legislative history.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about Ivanhoe?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: In Ivanhoe and Fresno, the Court, as we view the Court’s decisions, merely held that states could not override specific Congressional policies that had been established by Congress either in the Reclamation Act of 1902 or in later Acts.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they did say something about Section 8 specifically.
Do you agree with the language in Section 8?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: There was some certain language that appeared in those decisions that was strictly dictum, Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but do you disagree with them?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: If that dictum is construed against the position we are advocating, we certainly disagree with it.
It is possible, however, to construe that language only as coming to the conclusion that the states have no right to exercise any veto power over federal projects.
If that is the way you construe the language, then it is okay.
If it is construed more broadly, as United States would construe it, then we think it is inconsistent with the legislative history of the Reclamation Act of 1902 and thus is wrong.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was the 160-acre limitation written in by Congress under the 1902 Reclamation Act?

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: Yes, it was.

I do not want to discuss the conditions at length, but I do think that I should note to the Court that what the United States' argument before the Court today is somewhat different from representations that is already made to this Court with respect to the effect o the terms and conditions of Decision 1422.

The United States, in fact, advised this Court in another case that with respect to those conditions its only effect, that is Decision 1422’s only effect, would be to diverse slightly the beneficial use of the full conservation yield of the project.
Most of the project purposes were permitted by the Board’s decision.
The decision does not render the project useless or fundamentally alter its value.
Actually, if you examine the conditions themselves, you find that the United States’ former statement was quite true.

In fact, California provided, we think, a very balanced response in Decision 1422 to a situation that Congress completely overlooked and could not have foreseen when it authorized the New Melones Project.

Specifically, Congress, when it authorized that project intended for the waters to be used n a particular unit of the Central Valley Project known as the east side division, and Congress later abandoned plans for that project.
The Bureau of Reclamation has not developed any kind of alternative plans for that water.
So all the State Board did was this.
It simply deferred the Bureau’s right to full impoundment of water until the Bureau came up with a plan and submitted the plan to the State Board for its approval.
We think this is a very modest exercise of the right which the states have been given by Congress under Section 8.
The United States, in arguing that the states do not even have this right or essentially asking this Court to abrogate a fundamental and historic principle of the federal reclamation laws.
That principle, which has always been observed in actual historical practice, is that the states have an essential basic right to control how water is used under the Reclamation Act of 1902.
The United States in the final analysis is asking this Court to give it powers that it has never got from Congress.
We recommend that the appropriate solution for the United States is to go to Congress and not to come to this Court if it wants to overturn that principle.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: With respect to the interstate problem, I want to be sure I understand your position. That does not exist in this case. This is all in the intrastate, I presume it, but many would be --

turn.speaker: roderick_eugene_walston
turn.label: Mr. Roderick Eugene Walston
turn.text: That is correct.
In fact, Congress specifically amended Section 8 during the course of its passage of Section 8 during the 1902 Reclamation Act to specifically provide for that problem.
The appearance for the final solution appears and it is explained fully in our brief, Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
